Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Disinfection Properties of Visible Light Active Iron-containing Silicate Glass
Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to address current issues in global water quality and sustainability, new environmentally friendly water disinfection technologies must be developed. Currently, chemicals commonly used to disinfect wastewater, such as chlorine, can react with other molecules in the water to create potentially harmful disinfection byproducts (DBPs). New technologies using ultraviolet (UV) light and semiconducting materials may be a byproduct-free alternative to chemical disinfection to inactivate pathogenic bacteria. However, solar light has less than 5% UV light radiation and artificial source of UV-light makes UV technology expensive. This project will test the disinfecting capabilities of visible light active iron-containing silicate glass. The research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Shiro Kubuki, of Tokyo Metropolitan University (TMU) in Tokyo, Japan, who has developed an iron-containing silicate glass that can be easily activated by visible light. This specific type of glass can be prepared from recycled glass bottles, and uses visible light, rather than UV-light, making it a cost-effective, byproduct-free alternative to chemical disinfection.

Although it has been established that some semiconductors, such as titanium dioxide (TiO2), can effectively inactivate pathogenic bacteria, they require ultra-violet (UV) light to be effective. In this project, visible light active and iron-containing silicate glass will be used. Our hypothesis involves the use of iron-containing silicate glass made from recycled materials to eliminate pathogenic microorganisms without the harmful by-products produced by chlorine disinfectants and without the need for expensive and lengthy UV-light treatments. This study aims to: a) test the capability of iron-containing silicate glass to effectively inactivate pathogenic indicator organisms (Escherichia coli) by visible light-induced photocatalytic reaction and (b) explore the potential of using iron-containing silicate glass as an affordable "green" catalyst for water disinfection purposes.

This award is under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program support for a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAPSI Japan 2017 Project Outcomes Report

Research Title: Photocatalytic inactivation of Escherichia coli K-12 by iron-containing silicate glass

EAPSI Fellow: Kamrie Sarnosky, Texas A&M University, College Station, TX

EAPSI Host Advisor: Dr. Shiro Kubuki, Tokyo Metropolitan University, Tokyo, Japan

 

 

The work on this EAPSI-funded project is a step in the right direction for the use of chemistry and microbiology to innovate ways to treat water that are more cost-effective and less harmful. During my time in the radiology and microbiology laboratories at Tokyo Metropolitan University in Tokyo, Japan, I was able to practice my skills as a researcher by creating a study design and reaching a conclusion.

 

Dr. Kubuki’s iron-containing silicate glass was used to initiate a photocatalytic reaction and the viability of cells was measured using a plate-count method. Under several different experimental conditions, the photocatalytic effects of the iron-containing silicate glass did not appear to be effective at inhibiting cell viability. However, the experimental conditions also did not allow TiO2 to inhibit cell viability- even though it has been reported in several peer-reviewed publications. This indicates a flaw in the experimental set up, which time constraints did not allow to be addressed effectively.

 

This research contributes to the scientific community that under these experimental conditions with these particular photocatalytic materials, the viability of pathogenic indicator organisms is not inhibited. Other researchers may try different methods to find that the material will infact purify water without creating harmful disinfection byproducts.

 

Being a fellow for this research has taught me a lot as a young scientist on the importance of experimental design and the variability between laboratory projects. I was also able to collaborate with many Japanese scientists. The importance of international scientific collaboration is increasingly clear to all EAPSI fellows- which is promising as the next generation of scientists. This fellowship and its subsequent collaborations have been very useful to me in my academic career and I look forward to using these experiences in my scientific endeavors.
